The TooManyPathSegmentsDecideRule has simple logic: it'll definitely 
REJECT any URLs with more-than-the-desired number of '/' segments – and 
they'll only then be ruled-back in if a later rule says to ACCEPT. If 
you want to make sure it always 'wins' the decision, put it last.

If you're getting many/all URLs from hostnames that aren't on your seed 
sites, then specific rules/settings you've adjusted must be causing them 
to be ACCEPTed.

 From your description of the goal, I might try the approach of:

(1) Start with the default decide-rule based scope
(2) Set TransclusionDecideRule's maxTransHops to 0. Now, nothing that's 
off the starting domain will be ruled-ACCEPT simply because it appears 
to be an embedded/inline resource (IMG/FRAME/etc).
(3) Add your regex rule, to ACCEPT URLs ending with certain desired 
extensions (like '.exe'), at the very end of the rules. Then, no matter 
what the earlier decisions – perhaps REJECT because they're on other 
hostnames – the last winning decision will be ACCEPT.

If you're then getting more than expected, you need to look at the exact 
URL/discovery-hops to the unexpected URLs and figure out what ACCEPTed 
them. (Perhaps, a too-permissive regex?)

If you're getting less, you have to look at the discovery-hops that you 
expected to work to find the desired URL, and figure out which one was 
REJECTed. (Perhaps, the '.exe' etc URLs are more than 1-hop from your 
seed/starting domain, in which case you'll need to allow the intervening 
hops.)

Good luck!

- Gordon
